üíõ‚ö°Ô∏è Making things is incredibly rewarding‚Äîbut it's hard to balance with academic & social obligations. Purdue Hackers is a community of kind & creative people who make things together: apps, websites, games, generative art, hardware, whatever. There are three parts to Purdue Hackers:
- **Community:** A friendly & vibrant community on [our Discord](https://puhack.horse/discord). We share all upcoming events in there. - **Hack Night:** A hacker festival every Friday night, uninterrupted time for building projects. Come with your own projects, join a group, or just hang out! - **The Show:** A project showcase at the end of the semester once per year
Purdue Hackers is for you, whether you've never written code before, or are highly technical. All majors are welcome! We'd love to see you at our callout. To get an email reminder when it happens, sign up below.

BURST ‚ú∑ is a 4-hour pop-up gallery exhibition of creative technical projects, run by Purdue Hackers.

For 2 years, students in Purdue Hackers have been developing wacky, cutting-edge projects at Hack Night, our all-night hacker festival every Friday‚Äîbut none have been seen by anyone outside Hack Night.

On Sunday, December 8th, we‚Äôre installing these creations in the Rueff Galleries on campus in a first-of-its-kind exhibition for the broader campus community. They‚Äôll only be up for 4 hours, then never all in the same room again. Blink and you‚Äôll miss it.

Learn more: https://burst.purduehackers.com

üçÉ There's a message encoded in the vine. Can you figure out what it is?

You don't want to miss Hack Night 5.3. In addition to a night of working on your passion projects, Hack Night 5.3 includes a scavenger hunt. Your badge is one of 7‚Äîyou'll need to find 6 others, put your badges together, and decode the message in the vine. If you can do it before `0~0~0`, we'll buy you Insomnia.

Here's what's happening at Hack Night 5.3:

result.name: Hack Night 5.3
result.ogDescription: üåø There's a message waiting for you this Friday at Hack Night 5.3
result.pastEventDesc:
üåø Hack Night 5.3 was a special event. The badge was the best one we've ever made‚Äîit was 7 pieces of a hexagonal puzzle that, when assembled, revealed a message in a vine script that folks had to decode. The message led them to a website and a mysterious rotary phone placed in a corner of the Bechtel Center which contained another message. Those who made it all the way to the end received tickets which they redeemed for Insomnia cookies.

70 people joined us at Hack Night 5.3 and went on until 7:30. One group started a Rubik's cube computer, and someone else wrote a "brainfuck cpu" on their FPGA. People shared awesome things at Checkpoints as always.

üíõ‚ö°Ô∏è Making things is incredibly rewarding‚Äîbut it's hard to balance with academic & social obligations. Purdue Hackers is a community of kind & creative people who make things together: apps, websites, games, generative art, hardware, whatever. There are three parts to Purdue Hackers:

Come with your own projects, join a group, or just hang out!
Purdue Hackers is for you, whether you've never written code before, or are highly technical. All majors are welcome! We'd love to see you at our callout. To get an email reminder when it happens, sign up below.

result.ogDescription: üü°üé§ Make it rain colorful particles using your microphone and p5.js. No experience required.
result.pastEventDesc:
This was the third time we've run Sound Galaxy (see the [2021](https://events.purduehackers.com/sound-galaxy-2021) and [2022](https://events.purduehackers.com/sound-galaxy-2022) editions!). Sound Galaxy inspired our current workshop format: 30 minutes of coding together followed by 30 minutes of hacking‚Äîand it's our most successful version of this workshop format. We have yet to run another workshop whose hacking section looks quite like Sound Galaxy's: everyone quickly finds their own unique way to hack on the final product, and they make mind-blowing things. During this edition, more than 10 people stayed well after the scheduled end time of the workshop (7:30) to continue working, which rarely happens. Much üíõ to Sound Galaxy.

Check out some of our favorite hacks:

Get your golden tickets out...the next iteration of Hack Night is here: **Hack Night 2.0.**

Previously in a classroom in WALC, Hack Night now meets on the second floor of the Bechtel Center, Purdue's makerspace. Every event now has a color; this is "the gold one". Finally, an engineer from [Caesar Creek Software](https://www.cc-sw.com/) will be there to hack along with you. If you're looking for an internship, *bring your resume!*

Rich, vibrant, illuminated: this is how you you will feel hacking at the Bechtel center this Friday night! It will be amazing.

result.pastEventDesc:
Hack Night 2.0 happened on February 17th, 2023‚Äîand it was the best Hack Night yet. Previously in a classroom in WALC, with 2.0 Hack Night moved to the second floor of the [Bechtel Center](https://www.purdue.edu/bidc/), Purdue's makerspace. Bechtel is a wonderful fit for Hack Night‚Äîit's a beautiful space, surrounded by maker machines, and it feels like a hackathon venue. Hackers spread across the space, and it was a lot of fun. It was also our largest Hack Night, with 35 people.

Projects included a hardware clock for [Lightning Time](https://blog.purduehackers.com/posts/lightning-time), a camera that followed an object around the room, and a web app that lets you draw by moving your fingers around in front of your webcam.

This was "the gold event"; this week's badge was a Willy Wonka-inspired golden ticket laser cut out of gold acrylic.

We also had a sponsor: two engineers and a recruiter from [Caesar Creek Software](https://cc-sw.com) hacked along with students until 1:00 AM. They were a wonderful addition to the event!

result.desc:
üíõ‚ö°Ô∏è Purdue Hackers returns this Fall, bigger and better than ever ü•∞ We're a group of Purdue students who encourage each other to make our own creative projects with code. There are three parts to Purdue Hackers:
- **Community:** we have a friendly & vibrant community on [our Discord](https://bit.ly/PurdueHackersDiscord). - **Workshops:** we regularly run hour-long workshops to help you learn something new. [Check out an example of what people made at a previous workshop!](https://mbs.zone/sgdemo) (click or tap your screen to get it to work) - **Hack Night:** Every Friday night, we run Hack Night, a hackathon-style gathering where you have uninterrupted time to work on your own projects (with guidance where needed!)
Purdue Hackers is for you, whether you've never written code before, or are highly technical. All majors are welcome!
We'd love to see you at our callout. If you want to get a notification when it happens, please RSVP below (it also helps us know how many people we should expect).
result.name: Fall 2022 Callout
result.pastEventDesc:
On August 30, 2022, Purdue Hackers ran our Fall 2022 Callout‚Äîour largest event ever. Way more people showed up than we expected, and than had ever showed up Purdue Hackers history: a room with a capacity of ~80 was packed, with people along the walls & spilling out into the hallway (don't tell SAO üò≥).

Over 15 minutes, we briefly shared our philosophy, before inviting people to come up to chat & ask questions.

- [View the recording](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NutLx_8RisI)
- [View the slides we used](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1iQ8zrx__t07F5KbsJdWoE9yPwzdfslnh/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=105736452470826651375&rtpof=true&sd=true)

Calling all CS240 students! This Thursday, Purdue Hackers is running a workshop on using the GDB debugger.

If you want to stop debugging with `printf` & save hours on your future homework assignments, you won't want to miss this üòé
result.name: GDB Workshop
result.pastEventDesc:
Our second event of the Spring 2022 semester, the GDB workshop is an annual Purdue Hackers tradition: over an hour, we teach an audience of mostly freshmen how to use the GDB debugger‚Äîan essential tool for writing C and getting through CS 240.

30 people showed up this year. Pankaj was an amazing presenter, & nearly everyone walked out knowing how to use GDB. As a side quest, they also learned how `malloc()` works :)

**UPDATE 2/2**: due to the snowstorm & the subsequent closing of Purdue on Thursday, **this workshop will be held online.** The Zoom link will be posted in [our Discord](https://bit.ly/PurdueHackersDiscord)‚Äîplease join if you haven't already!

Calling anyone interested in Machine Learning! This workshop will cover a crash course on a ML algorithm. You'll learn all about how it works, and then we'll live code a project using it together :)
result.name: Machine Learning Workshop (for Beginners)
result.pastEventDesc:
Our first event of the Spring 2022 semester. For an hour, Nikita walked 80(!!!) people through making a simple word classifier machine learning app using Python on Google Colab.

This workshop was going to be held in person, but had to be moved online due to a massive snowstorm‚Äîthe largest in West Lafayette since 2007‚Äîwhich shut down the campus. Despite the last-minute change of plans, it was a huge success!

result.name: Spring 22 Callout
result.pastEventDesc:
Over 50 people came to our Spring 2022 callout, led by Matthew & Nikita. For ~20 minutes, we explained what Purdue Hackers is, and then we fielded questions from a large group of people who came up to the front for the next 30 minutes. The beginning of an amazing semester.

[Check out the slides we used!](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1axqCI-EgpnLBp5Ol-jczoCu4sHJ3FbcN/edit#slide=id.p1)

result.desc: Purdue Hackers presents a resume building workshop, where a guest speaker from the CCO will give a talk about what makes a good resume.
result.name: Resume Workshop
result.pastEventDesc: Our final event of the Fall 2021 semester, Purdue Hackers partnered with another student organization to organize a 30-minute talk on how to make your resume stand out to employers.

result.desc: Over an hour, you'll learn how to make colorful visuals with math & code‚Äîand then you'll be turned loose to make your own creations (don't worry, we'll be here to help if you get stuck!)
result.name: Sound Galaxy Workshop
result.pastEventDesc:
In November 2021, Purdue Hackers ran a workshop called Sound Galaxy, a web app that makes it rain particles on the screen based on the intensity of sound from your microphone. For 30 minutes, 7 people built this project from scratch using JavaScript, and for the second 30 minutes they built on top of it & made it totally their own.

Nearly everyone was a total beginner‚Äîand this project was both remarkably simple to build and intuitive to hack on. By the end of the meeting, every single person walked out with a fully original hack built on top of the base project.

result.name: Intro to IntelliJ
result.pastEventDesc: Our first event of the Fall 2021 semester, Purdue Hackers ran an hour-long workshop which walked freshmen through some interesting features of IntelliJ in order to help them with CS 180.
